titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thomas Davidson Papers
titlestmt.author: Revised by John Espy

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:04

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Correspondence, lectures, articles, printed matter, clippings, and film relating to the career of Davidson who came to the U.S. in 1867 and was associated with the St. Louis and Concord schools of philosophy, the founding of the Fellowship of the New Life, and the establishment of the Breadwinners' College. From 1878 to 1884, he was in Italy studying the writings of Antonio Rosmini-Serbati, about whom he published a study in 1882. The major portion of the papers is made up of correspondence, including letters from Henry Adams, John Dewey, Oliver Wendell Holmes, William James, Henry Cabot Lodge, John Stuart Mill, and Stephen Samuel Wise. Only a few pages of his diary of 1858 survive. Also with the papers is material from Edward Endelman, a student of Davidson's. Of particular interest is Endelman's correspondence about Davidson with William T. Harris, a Hegelian philosopher who had been a close friend of Davidson's. In addition, two reels of microfilm collected by John Roemischer which contain letters and articles by Davidson in other repositories have been added to the papers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Thomas Davidson Papers (MS 169). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Charles M. Bakewell, 1944 and 1956; William A. Kurlane, 1961; Mrs. Edward Endelman, 1959; and John Roemischer, 1975. Also by purchase in 1963.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in five series: I. Correspondence. II. Writings. III. Writings about Davidson. IV. Miscellaneous Papers and Memorabilia. V. Edward Endelman Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In some ways, these papers present Davidson the educator more than Davidson the student of philosophy. Although his scholarly interests are well represented here, in articles, notes, and translations, one is struck by the number of public lectures and popular essays. Even the notes are often drafted in the style of his lectures. The teaching materials in Series II, WRITINGS, and IV, MISCELLANEOUS PAPERS AND MEMORABILIA, and the papers of his student, Edward Endelman, in Series V, serve to reinforce this impression.

The papers are organized as follows: Series I, CORRESPONDENCE, alphabetically arranged; Series II, WRITINGS, alphabetical for the most part; Series III, WRITINGS ABOUT DAVIDSON; Series IV, MISCELLANEOUS PAPERS AND MEMORABILIA; and Series V, EDWARD ENDELMAN PAPERS. Additional Davidson materials are available on microfilm; a listing of these follows the listing of the papers themselves.

Prominent correspondents include Henry Adams, John Dewey, Edward Emerson, William Torrey Harris, Oliver Wendell Holmes, William James, Henry Cabot Lodge, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, John Stuart Mill, Josiah Royce, and Stephen Samuel Wise, but most of the correspondents are not well known. There are only a few of Davidson's own letters in the papers.

Scattered throughout Series II-V are notes and transcripts by John Roemischer and (more frequently) photocopies of Davidson material with Roemischer's annotations. Folders which contain only Roemischer's notes on a Davidson essay, without some form of the essay itself, are identified in the listing by the words "(notes only)."
The papers were given by Charles M. Bakewell, William H. Kurlans, and Edward Endelman. The microfilm was the gift of Dr. Roemischer.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Thomas Davidson: taught Latin and Greek in Tunbridge Wells and Wimbledon, England, 1863-1866; taught and became a principal in the public school system of St. Louis, beginning in 1868; active in circle of Hegelian philosophers in St. Louis; in 1875 moved to Boston and became freelance writer and teacher at private schools; from 1878-1884 spent much time in Italy in close contact with the Rosminian order; in 1883 founded the Fellowship of the New Life in London; later founded a Breadwinners' College in New York City; author of numerous books and articles.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folders with asterisks(*) contain ten or more items

did.unittitle: Lectures, Articles, and Books (NOTE: asterisk indicates presence of Davidson MS)

"Union of Hebrew Prophecy with Greek Philosophy"(*)
"The Form in which Ancient Thought appears in the Modern World"(*)
"Christian Unity, or the Kingdom of Heaven"
"The Conditions, Divisions and Methods of Complete Education"
Correspondence with W.T. Parkinson re: review of Father Pesch
"The Creed of the Sultan: Its Future"
"[ The Development of Christian Doctrine to the Council of Nicea ?]"(*)
"Faith as a Faculty of the Human Mind"
"Greek at Harvard," and related letter to editor
[ The Hebrew or Prophetic Element in Dogma ? or The Semitic Element in Medieval Philosophy ?](*)
"A Hymeneal for the Marriage of Man with Liberty"(*)
"The Ideal Training of an American Boy"
Letters to members of his classes (*)
Letters from Hurricane, N.Y. to Breadwinners Class "Monad," "Substance," "Parmenides"
"The Moral Aspects of the Economic Question"
New York People's Institute: untitled account of classes
"The Philosophic Movement in the Roman Church"
"The Problems set by the Nineteenth Century to the Twentieth": 2 lectures (out of 4?) (*)
"Religion, or Mythology, Theology, and Worship of the Greeks"(*)
Reviews (alphabetical by author of work reviewed.)
"The Revival of Thought in Europe in the Thirteenth Century: Aristotle in the Schools"(*)
"Rosmini Falsamente Accusato Dinanzi a Leone XIII"
"When the 'Higher Criticism' has done its Work"
"Why has Unreasoning Faith Always Dethroned Religion?"
"Zionism from a non-Jewish Point of View"(*)
On education (book-length: contents, bibliography, and pp. 353-417, 436) (*)
On Dante as an epochal poet(*)
Translations (NOTE: asterisk indicates presence of Davidson MSS)
"Aristotle's Metaphysics : A Translation of the Eleventh Book"
"Translation of a Part of Rosmini's Aristotle (*)"
Ibn Gabirol, Al Forabi, William of Auvergne, and Averroës
Marcion, Neo-Platonism, Numenius, Mani, Ibn Sînâ, and Maimonides
Scholasticism, sketch of Mediaeval Christian Literature, Conceptualism, St. Bonaventura, and Nicene Creed
Literary fragments by and copied by Davidson
The Fellowship of the New Life
Syllabus and study questions on Aristotle; syllabus, on dramatic poetry
Tsedek, Rolfe: articles on Davidson in the Daily Jewish Herald
Bibliography (prepared by William T. Harris) and notes on Davidson's papers
William T. Harris, "Thomas Davidson's Theory of Man and the World: A Critique of his Psychologic Foundation"
Charles M. Bakewell, notes for dissertation on Davidson
The Thomas Davidson Society: correspondence, reports, questionnaires, records of attendance
Correspondence re: lecture arrangements, with some printed matter
Printed lecture announcements and course bulletins, and MS treasurer's reports
Letters of introduction, invitations, testimonials, with some printed matter, calling cards, etc.
Annotated research material: reprints of others' articles, etc.
(Most of this material pertains to Davidson; it includes correspondence about him, and papers prepared for his classes, with an occasional note by him.)
"Paper for Memorial at Glenmore" and "History of Class"
"Hume's Fallacy and the Doctrine of Causation" (M.A. thesis, N.Y.U.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These films were collected and donated by John Roemischer. They were filmed between 1961 and 1964, at the following institutions: nos. 2-5, 7-10, and 12 at the New York Public Library; no. 1 at Harvard University Library; no. 6 at Yale University Library; no. 11 at the University of California at Berkley; no. 13 at the American Jewish Periodical Center in Cincinnati; and no. 15 at Queen's University of Belfast. There is no record of the filming of no. 14.
The present film consists of the following 15 negative films, spliced together on two reels.

scopecontent.p: WTH (superintendent), various reports from vols. 14-20, 25, expressing his educational philosophy.
